author: @Kartikrvs

text:
Hello there,
I am Badri and I have bought iQube S on april 2023. I would like to bring up an issue to you as I saw your reviews before actually trusting this scooter. I have a strange issue with the scooter and would like to confirm it is present in all iQube scooters or only present in mine. The issue is if i travel in eco mode for say 25kms then the scooter is fine, but in power mode if i were to use full throttle then it would run into problems. First it would show an exclamation triangle while riding and if i switch off the vehicle and turn it in it would refuse to run ( Error code 002). This happened for me 2 times one at 7200kms when vehicle was in TVS service center for 3 months and the service engineers and tvs didn't know what was the problem and i later got the scooter and they did not explain me what was the problem. Second was at 8100 kms when vehicle suddenly stopped again ( this time also it happened when i drove the vehicle in power mode) - this time the vehicle did not move and screen froze but it showed no error so again I sent it to service center and it was a problem with relay and they returned the vehicle in 4 days. Now the vehicle is fine and running good. But i am afraid of driving it in power mode with speeds above 72kmph. Can you please advice on this? Is it problem in my vehicle only or all the iQube scooters?

text:
Been owning Iqube for 2 years now 

Performance is adequate but but but ....
Build quality is horrible 
1. The rear mud flaps are mounted to the right and left shield which is plastic. Indian roads arnt that good cuz if vibration the clamps get damaged, there's actually no fix for it, you have to replace both the shields which costs you around 9500 just to fix your mudflap ....

2. Hub motor is really week 50 kmph+ accidentally if you run over a pot hole it will bend the rims, again only fix is to replace the hub motor which is 46K 🤦‍♂️ 
You can't claim insurance because it's considered as wheel bend according to their T&C ...

author: @mastjaat1111

text: I am one of the first batch owners of the i Qube electric scooter, and I would highly recommend it for city use. The primary appeal for me was its size—it looks like a conventional scooter, unlike many other models in the market that are lean and tiny. Being 6 feet tall, I found the i Qube more suitable for my build. The 75 km range is ideal for city commuting, and the range indicator is highly accurate, eliminating any anxiety about running out of charge. However, one downside is the Hub motor—it performs well but makes changing the rear tyre a hassle, as it requires a trip to the service center. And yes, the Regen does a pretty good Job at bringing the scooter to a stop!!!

text:
My 2023 Aug model iQube after 1 y 5 m and 31000 kms, now is resting in TVS service centre for last two weeks for hub motor malfunction. 

Till 30k, everything was smooth and fine, until one day they recalled for inspecting chassis and eventually replacing it.

They told they would rectify the issue under warranty. Imagine having chassis and motor of a ev replaced within one and half years. All left is just the battery and hoping to get it replaced within warranty period!

Great job TVS 🎉

author: @rahultalari1241

text:
I own an iQube 2.2kWh (Purchased: April 2021). My daily commute is around 20 km per day, split equally between city and highway rides.
In the city, the iQube is an absolute breeze to ride—quick, smooth, and very enjoyable. However, as Schumi pointed out, it starts feeling a bit bouncy and less confidence-inspiring at higher speeds, particularly around 60 km/h on highways. That said, the ride quality is exceptionally smooth and glides effortlessly.

I also own a Jupiter 110 (2022), and comparing the two, the Jupiter feels lighter and more flickable, which makes it slightly more fun to maneuver. The suspension on the Jupiter is also well-balanced, giving it a more composed ride overall.

That said, I did face two accidents on the iQube. Thankfully, I only suffered minor injuries, and the scooter didn’t sustain any major damages. However, the rear tire began separating from the hub motor due to low tire pressure (my fault), and the side-stand cutoff sensor was damaged. As a result, the scooter was undrivable, and I had to get it repaired.

Unfortunately, my first service center experience was terrible. The staff were rude and unhelpful, and customer care wasn’t much better. It was so frustrating that after my second accident, I seriously considered selling the scooter and switching to an Ather. However, a new service center opened just 2 km from my home, and my experience with them has been completely different—super welcoming staff, no hassles, and a positive overall experience. It just goes to show how much the dealership/service center matters.

A couple of minor issues I’d like to point out:

Torque Dump Issue: When you turn off the scooter in park mode and later turn it back on to ride, the motor dumps the entire torque when you open the throttle. This can cause the rear wheel to spin up unexpectedly, potentially making you lose control. Regen doesn’t work during this, but if you turn the scooter off and back on, it works normally again. While I find this flaw enjoyable because of the extra power, i play with it in controlled environments, it’s definitely not safe for public roads.

Park Mode Warning: If you engage park mode for about 2 mins, and then try to switch to riding mode, the scooter throws a warning and doesn’t respond to any inputs. Again, turning it off and back on fixes the issue.

I asked both service centers about these problems. The first one completely ignored the issues, but the second one identified the cause and applied a minor software fix, which resolved the second issue. The first issue persists, but I don’t mind it.

Aside from these minor quirks and my initial service issues, I’ve thoroughly enjoyed the iQube overall, its a good purchase.

author: @blazingskulls

text:
22:45 i have the base iqube 2.2 and i dont want my scooter to switch to power when i open the throttle. my mother uses the scooter as well and we need the scooter to be predictable. 
Besides, the button to switch is right there where the ignition button is so its v convenient to switch to power and switch back when *you* want. 
so for someone who wants control about what the bike does (me) and for someone who doesnt want a sudden boost in performance (mother) the automation by the scooter is not desirable

author: @bickiethomas1832

text:
iQube 2022 base model owner here!   IMO...
(In the ₹90k to ₹110k price range)
 iQube base model is just a better (if not the best) scooter!

I was coming off a 2011 Access, in the market to buy a jupiter or Activa!
I started considering an electric scooter because of the "ev-wave"

I hadn't heard of TVS iQube back then. When I checked the options in the market and we took the test rides... the choice was obvious!

We did all the money saving calculations... but it didn't matter!
Because, iQube was just a better scooter! 

The pin drop silence and vibration-less driving feels like therapy, if you are coming from an ICE scooter.
So silent that the only noise you here is of the plastic panels squeeking.
The suspension is definitely a luxury!

And, as a family scooter... I wasn't looking for features and connectivity, nor did  I want to pay more for it!

 I wanted it to fit seamlessly in my parents' lives. By functioning just like an ICE scooter!
And an EV  can't get any closer to a Jupiter .... than iQube!

You put the key in, Push the SAME start button for 2-3 secs, and you go!!

No passwords, no remote unlocks! No touch screen!! 
just less things to take care of!!
No explanations and learning needed.

There is never a lack of performance, nor does it surprise you with sudden power!
Regen works predictably enough that I can ride without using the brake!
And I ride in Eco mode always, so it gives 95km-100km of range against the claimed 105km.


2+ years in.... I am a very happy customer. 
I have just a 10-20km daily commute... if I exclude weekends,  I literally end up charging once a week!

At first I thought, charge anxiety would be a worry .... 
but now having the convenience to charge at home whenever I want, instead of waiting in line at the petrol pump ... is actually a plus point!

Like Shumi rightly pointed out, The boot release and charging plug is a finicky thing. But not a deal breaker!

If you are someone who does a daily commute of 10-20km commute.... and you are in the market to buy an Activa or Jupiter... Then, don't be stuck on ICE scooters only ...thinking "my commute isn't long enough for an ev"

You get a lot for the ₹15-20k that you pay more than an ICE.
And, People still pay more for a Vespa!
IMO, this iQube can even be a Default choice - like Shumi rightly said!

maine bhi 1 sal pahle hi li thi 30000 km pe battery kharab ho gayi , warranty me thi to showroom walo ne change karke di lekin uske liye 20 din lag gaye , lekin warrenty khatm hone par to 50000 km ke liye 60000 rs. ki battery to 1.20 rs to battery kharcha ho gaya aur 30 paisa to electricity ka matlab bachega sirf 40/50 paisa per km aur kuch bhi problem ho to scooter kisi gadi me load karke le jana padata hai ,

are Technology aur features ki Aisi Ki Taisi

text: Worst electric scooter of world…And worst after sales experience
author: @sunandanmahapatra5875

text:
I've spent a lot of time watching dozens of videos and reading countless comments about the comparison between Ola and TVS iQube electric scooters. From what I've gathered, Ola users seem to be facing a lot of issues with their scooters, ranging from poor service to quality concerns. On the other hand, TVS iQube owners appear to be very happy and satisfied, with no significant problems reported.
As an interior designer, I need a reliable scooter for visiting my projects within the city. I was initially drawn to Ola because of its energetic appeal and modern design. However, after seeing all the negative reviews and the frequent issues reported by users, I've reconsidered my choice.
I believe it's better to go with TVS iQube. It may not have the same flashy appeal as Ola, but its reliability and the positive feedback from current owners make it a more sensible choice for my needs. After all, having a dependable scooter is crucial for my work and peace of mind.
